text: (upbeat music)
- My name is Fabrizio Conicella.

I'm Head of Digital
and Advanced Technology
in Iveco Group.

Iveco Group is a
multifunctional company making,

building, and designing light,
medium, and heavy trucks

as well as buses, powertrain
units, and specialty vehicles

with particular focus on
off-road, firefighting
and military missions.

Basically, our challenge
is to serve our customers
with the highest quality products,

always taking care of
their business as well.

So improving and reducing
overall costs, operating cost,
as well as improving uptime and safety,
and the comfort for our drivers.
(upbeat music)
- We started with the innovation path,
helping them apply the methodology,
writing their PRFAQ,

also defining the full
customer experiences
with the innovation program teams.

What I found great about
our collaboration was also

the fact that it was
not a one-time activity
that we have done together,
but the fact that we embraced

and we embarked in multiple
streamlines together.
What was the main takeaway you took
from the multiple workshop and activities,
the team has led with you?
- Well, first of all

the way to be more, let's
say, customer-centric.

So to have a customer at
the center of our vision,

and then to avoid starting
from the solution,
like a lot of engineers usually do.

But we were starting from the
real customer pain points,
so the issues,

and then working backwards
we were able to identify
how to fix the issues and then
at a really later stage, the solution.

And then we were able
to build a prototype,
a pilot, together.

- I really love how you
are really pushing ahead
in this automating part

and pushing ahead in
the sustainability part.
Definitely.
And in the safety, I mean

when you're saying of
course you need to balance
between one part that would be driverless,

one part that will be
driven by an actual person,
how you balance this part of the safety.
How do you think of doing that

and how AWS is helping you
define what to develop?

- So we are cooperating, first
of all, in the innovation

with AWS in terms of
working back methodology

which allow us also to
invent other products,

like the driver assistant
that we call Driver Pal.
But also for the automation,
we will be working on data collection

with a very powerful
cloud, machine learning,

artificial intelligence,
labeling, and also HD maps

which are also very
important for the automation.
And so we are cooperating on that,
and we start the pilot this year.
(upbeat music)
- We started together our journey in 2019,

and we started to innovate
in different streams.

Could you tell us more about
Iveco's future business model?
- As you know, the future vehicles,

civil emission vehicles, are
becoming more expensive, right?
So BEV and fuel cell.

So we were thinking to
study something different.
- Yeah.
- To offer these tracks to our customer

with the new business
model based on pay-per-use.
- So data is the core of your strategy.

How do you think that
data, but mainly also AWS,

could you support more and more
in your innovation journey?
- First of all, we are in AWS cloud

so we rely, of course on
AWS products, in this case.

And we expect to work
together to cooperate
in order to have a machine learning,
artificial intelligence behind,
and establish the appropriate, let me say,

analysis of the mission
and associated evaluation
of the restore value and the hourly cost.

Just using data coming from
our connected vehicles.

- So mean that the new
way to comprehend data
and help you to become more and more

a data-driven company
to support your customer
in a new business way.

- Exactly.
Yeah.

Safety is extremely
important for our vehicles.

So on top of the more advanced
data that we are developing
in compliance also with GSR regulations,

we launched the Driver Pal,
our innovative and disruptive
driver assistant based on Alexa vocal data

with a very clear objective
to improve the safety
and the comfort for our drivers.

In fact, they can
basically actuate any kind
of car functionalities just vocally

without removing their hands
from the steering wheel.

Then we will work in the next
step, which is the level four,

which can be also at least in
part of the mission driverless

but we still believe in
the driver to be in the cab

even if the work of the driver
and the life of the driver
on board will change dramatically.

- What we're witnessing here,
it's a manufacturing company

like Iveco, really moving
from creating trucks
and from a really hardware model

into developing new
services for their drivers,

for their partners, and really
moving all the business model

to create a differentiating
customer experience

that will make them
unique in their industry.
- We are definitely improving several KPIs
since we are working in digital
and also advanced technology
and also in cooperation with AWS.

We are certainly improving
reduction of unplanned stops
by 20% back to last year.

And now we are planning to
increase up to 40% this year
thanks to the predictive analytics.
Which is based on digital twins,

which are reproducing the
way our systems are working.

And so they allow us to
understand the state of health

in real time and to anticipate
any kind of breakdown

and to inform the customer
so that he can plan the stop
at his most convenient time
without disrupting their business.

Before we were working
with a reactive approach
because we were not using data.
So data is the key.

- So I think that the
uniqueness of the collaboration

between Amazon Web Services
and Iveco stands really

in the fact of the alignment
of our leadership principles.
And really the value of Iveco

to have this customer
centricity really strong
aligned with our customer obsession,
the way we drive products

and services, and our
sustainability values.
